topic.title: SFR: MODFLOW 6 Streamflow Routing Package Pane

para.text: SFR: MODFLOW 6 Streamflow Routing Package Pane

The Streamflow Routing package in MODFLOW-2005 organizes stream reaches into stream segments. Connections between reaches in the same segment are identified automatically whereas the modeler must specify connections among stream segments. In MODFLOW 6, only reaches are defined and the modeler must specify all connections among reaches. In ModelMuse, the connections among stream reaches specified by the same object are identified automatically. The modeler must assign a segment number to each object and these are used to identify connections among stream reaches specified using different objects. This segment number is not part of the input to MODFLOW 6 but instead is used as a way of simplifying the input for the user.

Segments must be defined with point or polyline objects. The first vertex in the object defining the stream is at the upstream end of the stream. You can reverse the order of the vertices in an object using "Object|Edit|
There are the following tabs on this pane. (Some may be hidden.)

tab is used to specify properties of the stream that do not change over time. these include the reach length and width, the gradient, the streambed top and thickness, and the hydraulic conductivity of the streambed material.

li.text: If a cross section will be defined for the reaches, the
edit box should be set to "
". If either of these is selected, the
" is selected, the cross section will apply for the duration of the model. If "
" is selected, the first cross section will apply from the start of the model until the next cross section is applied. Each cross section will remain in effect until another one is selected.
is the reach length. RLEN must be greater than zero.
is the reach width. RWID must be greater than zero.
is the stream gradient (slope) across the reach. RGRD must be greater than zero.
the top elevation of the reach streambed.
is the thickness of the reach streambed. RBTH can be any value if the reach is in a vertical pass-through cell. Otherwise, RBTH must be greater than zero.
is the hydraulic conductivity of the reach streambed. RHK can be any positive value if the reach is in a vertical pass-through cell. Otherwise, RHK must be greater than zero.

is the head in the stream at the beginning of the simulation. initial stage data are used only if STORAGE is specified in the Options block and the first stress period is transient or for reaches defined to use the SIMPLE STATUS in the Period block. The initial stage must be greater than or equal to the streambed top.

para.text: tab is used to specify properties of the stream that can vary among stress periods. These include

, the status (active, inactive, or specified head), the stream stage, flows into or out of the stream (Inflow, rainfall, evaporation, and runoff), the streambed roughness, the fraction of flows from upstream reaches that is applied as inflow to the first reach in this segment, and the diversion rate for any diversions..

li.text: can be Active, Inactive or Specified. In active segments, the head is calculated from the flow. Inactive segments are not part of the model. If Status is Specified, the modeler specifies a head that interacts with the aquifer.
is the stage for the reach.
is the volumetric inflow rate for the first streamflow routing reach in a segment.
is the volumetric rate per unit area of water added by precipitation directly on each streamflow routing reach.
is the volumetric rate per unit area of water subtracted by evaporation from each streamflow routing reach.
is the volumetric rate of diffuse overland runoff that enters each streamflow routing reach.
is the Manning’s roughness coefficient for the reach. Roughness must be greater than zero.
If a stream segment has upstream tributaries that feed into it, the upstream fraction is the fraction of the flow from the upstream tributaries that flow into it. Normally,

is set to 1. However, is the flow from an upstream tributary segment is divided into two or model downstream segment, the sum of the upstream fractions of all the segments that receive the flow must add up to 1. If a segment is a diversion,
: Density is the density of fluid entering groundwater from the stream. Density is only present if the
package is active and Specify Density is selected.
: Viscosity is the viscosity of fluid entering groundwater from the stream. Viscosity is only present if the
package is active and Specify Viscosity is selected.
is the volumetric diversion (DIVFLOW) rate for the streamflow routing reach. Diversions are specified on the
tab. The actual rate of diversion is determined by the priority of the diversion.

para.text: tab is used to specify the segments downstream of the current segment that receive flow from the current segment. If there is more than one downstream segment, be sure that the

for those segments add up to 1. If the user clicks in the table square where the segment number is specified a button with the label "Closest" will appear. Clicking that button will cause the segment number of the SFR segment whose upstream end is closest to the downstream end of the current segment to be entered in the table cell.

tab is used to specify upstream segments from which this segment diverts flow and the priority for each diversion. Choices for the priority are FRACTION, EXCESS, THRESHOLD, and UPTO. See the MODFLOW 6 documentation for explanations of these options. Note that the diversion rates for diversions is specified on the

li.text: is the segment number of another SFR segment from which flow is diverted. Flow is diverted from the downstream end of the current segment into the upstream end of the other segment.
can be "Fraction," "Excess," "Threshold," or "Up to." The choice determines how the diversion rate specified on the Rates tab is used to calculate the amount of flow diverted.

list.style: text-indent:0px; margin-right:0px; margin-left:37px; tabstops:none; font-family:Wingdings; font-size:12pt; color:#000000;

li.text: : The amount of the diversion is computed as a fraction of the streamflow leaving reach the last reach of the segment (QDS); in this case, 0.0 ≤ DIVFLOW ≤ 1.0.

A diversion is made only if QDS for the last reach of the segment exceeds the value of DIVFLOW. If this occurs, then the quantity of water diverted is the excess flow (QDS - DIVFLOW) and QDS from reach RNO is set equal to DIVFLOW. This represents a flood-control type of diversion, as described by Danskin and Hanson (2002).

If QDS in the last reach of the segment is less than the specified diversion flow (DIVFLOW), no water is diverted from the last reach of the segment . If QDS in the last reach of the segment is greater than or equal to (DIVFLOW), (DIVFLOW) is diverted and QDS is set to the remainder (QDS - DIVFLOW)). This approach assumes that once flow in the stream is sufficiently low, diversions from the stream cease, and is the ‘priority’ algorithm that originally was programmed into the STR1 Package (Prudic, 1989).

If QDS in the last reach of the segment is greater than or equal to the specified diversion flow (DIVFLOW), QDS is reduced by DIVFLOW. If QDS in the last reach of the segment is less than (DIVFLOW), DIVFLOW is set to QDS and there will be no flow available for reaches connected to downstream end of the last reach of the segment.

para.text: The Cross Section tab is used to specify the shape of the cross section and (optionally) the Manning's Roughness for different sections of the cross section. It only appears if

", the times at which different cross sections will apply are set in a table on the left side of the pane. A separate cross section is associated with each row of the table with the times. The user can edit the cross section associated with each row by selecting a row in the table with the times.
The X coordinates of the cross section are specified as fractions of the channel width. However, the fractions can be greater than 1.
The Y coordinates of the cross section are specified as heights above the bottom elevation of the channel. The lowest height must be zero.

If the Manning's roughness varies across the channel, the user can specify a Manning's roughness ratio for each specified point in the cross section. The applied Manning's roughness will be the channel roughness times the ratio. The roughness fraction applies from the point at which it is specified to the next point so the roughness fraction for the last point has no effect.
A plot of the cross section data is displayed beneath the table in which the data is specified. Color is used to indicate where varying values of the roughness are applied.
More information on channel cross sections is in mf6io.pdf which is included in the MODFLOW 6 distribution.
The GWT tab is used for specifying data for the SFT package in groundwater transport. This tab is only visible if groundwater transport is active.
The left hand side has a list of the chemical species used in the model. For each chemical species, the user specifies the initial concentration and transient data for the species.

can be ACTIVE, INACTIVE, or CONSTANT. By default, STATUS is ACTIVE, which means that concentration will be calculated for the reach. If a reach is inactive, then there will be no solute mass fluxes into or out of the reach and the inactive value will be written for the reach concentration. If a reach is constant, then the concentration for the reach will be fixed at the user specified value.
defines the concentration for the reach. The specified CONCENTRATION is only applied if the reach is a constant concentration reach.
defines the concentration of evaporated water (ML
) for the reach. If this concentration value is larger than the simulated concentration in the reach, then the evaporated water will be removed at the same concentration as the reach.
) for the reach. Value must be greater than or equal to zero.
) for the reach. Value must be greater than or equal to zero.
